title: Windows Installation Repeatedly Fails To Complete

forumNotes.author: Guest_AnonVendetta_*
forumNotes.content:
I've been having an issue as of very recently, which is that no matter which version of Windows I try to install, the setup simply wont finish after the initial reboot. It always BSODs, with either "bugcode_usbdriver" or "an attempt was made to execute to non-executable memory". Or it will hang on the 7/8.1 boot logo and never go further. Thusfar I have tried Server 2008 R2 x64, 7 Enterprise x64, and 8.1 Enterprise x64. All are uncracked, original volume licensing Microsoft ISOs, obtained from various sources, md5 and sha1 hashes checked against what Microsoft provides. If/when the bugcode_USB BSOD occurs, no USB device is plugged in. Strangely enough, various Linuxes install fine.

I opted to install in UEFI mode, with imagex, and bcdboot to install boot files. I cant use the regular Windows GUI setup, because I have 1 EFI on each of my laptop's internal drive, which confuses the setup, with error "We couldnt create a new partition or locate an existing one". Both drives are pre-partitioned with GParted:

imagex /apply Z:\\sources\\install.wim 1 C:

and

bcdboot C:\\Windows /l en-US /s A: /f ALL

C is Windows destination partition, A: is EFI. The /f ALL variable was only used with 8.1, it isnt a valid parameter for 7 and 2008 R2. I used GetWAIKTools to obtain the needed files, using the appropriate version of imagex and bcdboot as per the desired OS. Install files and tools were placed on a FAT32 partition (1st partition) on an external USB HDD. I booted the installer with UEFI DUET, since my UEFI BIOS seems to be unable to boot from any partition on a USB in UEFI mode. It only seems to boot in native UEFI (no DUET) if the boot files are on the 1st partition (unsure about this) of my laptop's primary drive in the master slot. I recently installed an optical drive caddy, containing a Seagate 2TB drive. UEFI booting from anywhere on that drive seems impossible (directly, without chainloading), it simply isnt an available boot option in my BIOS.

After installing via DUET completes, I power off and natively UEFI boot without DUET, Windows logo appears to complete install, and BAM, shortly thereafter, the BSOD or hang almost always occurs (finally managed to install 8.1today without crashing, but it took several tries, following my above steps, which I know to be correct). I believe this is a deeper symptom of a hardware issue, but need help determining which component(s) is fail(ing). Possibles:

1. Modded BIOS ( I cant boot in native UEFI mode with any other flashed BIOS, except via DUET, everything has been reset to defaults in BIOS, except that UEFI and "UEFI boot first" has been selected)

2. Bad RAM (need to run extended tests with MemTest86+, planning to replace my current 6GB with 16GB soon)

3. Bad drive in primary master slot (tests indicate that is has several hundred bad sectors thusfar, but it still boots and \*seems\* fine for now.

4. Bad HDD in optical caddy (unlikely since the drive was just bought and installed last week), I'm not booting from it anyway.

5. Both drives may be causing a power surge that is too much for my laptop's power supply/brick to handle (150 watts rated), therefore not supplying enough power. See my question on superuser.com regarding a similar issue with a previous laptop, current PC doesnt seem to have said issue:

[http://superuser.com...-in-windows-8-1](http://superuser.com/questions/862980/secondary-internal-hdd-vanishes-reappears-randomly-in-windows-8-1 "External link")

6. Bad USB ports (unlikely, all seem to work fine with my devices, in both 2.0 and 3.0 modes)

7. Bad battery (testing indicates my battery is failing, it doesnt hold much of a charge even when not gaming, and drains somewhat fast).

8. Installing in UEFI/GPT mode instead of BIOS/MBR mode.

This isnt technically related to booting, and I know reboot.pro isnt a general tech support forum, but I'd appreciate some help with this nonetheless. None of this wasnt occuring as of several days ago.

Thanks in advance!

**Edited by AnonVendetta, 20 April 2015 - 05:08 PM.**

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> no matter which version of Windows I try to install, the setup simply wont finish after the initial reboot.
Replace the broken hardware. Or replace the hardware relating software, BIOS or drivers.  

As for testing: strip down the machine, remove as much parts as possible.  
Try a OS default installation.  

Make small steps. Don't make assumptions, ignore logic. Make semingly random testings.  

> UEFI DUET
As for testing: well you won't like the suggestion.  

> 3. Bad drive in primary master slot (tests indicate that is has several hundred bad sectors thusfar, but it still boots and \*seems\* fine for now.
Primary suspect, replace this one first. Can be another reason still.  
Or zero windows partition several times and listen:  
any strange seek noises?

forumNotes.author: RoyM
forumNotes.content:
Hi AnonVendetta  
cdob is spot on with his suggestions.  
I wholeheartedly agree with his "Primary suspect", "Oh, and replace the battery".  
Typical hardware troubleshooting goes like this.  
Strip down to bare minimum: Power Supply, Mboard, Mem, HD.  
Once this is done, troubleshooting can begin.  
Substitute above parts with "KNOWN GOOD", not just suspected good,  
I mean, parts that have been verified as 100% good hardware, tested and verified.  
Be sure to disconnect or remove any other hardware, network, wifi, cd, etc, etc.  
If it cannot be removed or disconnected, then at the very least, disabled in BIOS.  
substitute out, pwr supply, memory, harddrive, with your "KNOWN GOOD" hardware.  
run it through it's paces and try to make it fail as before, if you are successful, with no failures,  
then replace only ONE (1) peice of hardware at a time with original hardware, then retest.  
It's basicaly a process of elimination, without super expensive tools and equipment, this is what MUST be done.  
Happy troubleshooting!!!.  
Regards  
RoyM

forumNotes.author: Guest_AnonVendetta_*
forumNotes.content:
I will try flashing the latest A08 (official, unmodded) BIOS and install in BIOS/MBR mode (since the official BIOS has the UEFI option hidden), I doubt it will make a difference. And I will try again later, once again, with the modded BIOS I'm currently using.

The RAM I have may or may not be bad, I have good mind to run tests with MemTest86+ overnight tonight for several hours, to see what the results are. I can also try removing one stick or the other and booting with just one. One stick is 4GB, the other is 2GB. All recent Windows OSes can still boot with 2GB RAM, albeit slower. The question, of course, is determining which one is bad, if either. But I consider it a moot point,since I'll be replacing them next month anyway.

As for nthe HDDs, the 2TB Seagate in the caddy slot is certainly good, and practically new, I can try removing the caddy, and swapping the 2TB into the primary master slot, booting with only one drive, which would also (hopefully) eliminate any chance of power overdraw on the power supply. But that will mean I will have to install on GPT partitioning, given the size. Or with DUET. I suspect DUET isn't the issue anyways, it was and still continues to work fine.

USB ports obviously can't be removed, but I'll see if they can be disabled in BIOS, or at least set to legacy compatibility mode. I'll need them to install an OS anyway, but can try to disable them before allowing Windows to complete setup after the initial reboot that the GUI installer does.

Replacing the battery isn't possible yet, but I can try to install without the battery, with only the AC adapter plugged in. To be precise, the power supply/brick itself is fine, it's the battery that's bad. And I haven't found any PSUs for my model (Dell, 3rd party, or otherwise) that are rated for higher than 150 watts (what I currently have). Both battery and PSU are stock.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> As for nthe HDDs, the 2TB Seagate in the caddy slot is certainly good, and practically new, I can try removing the caddy, and swapping the 2TB into the primary master slot, booting with only one drive, which would also (hopefully) eliminate any chance of power overdraw on the power supply. ++But that will mean I will **have to**++ install on GPT partitioning, ++given the size++.

Last time I checked MBR style of partitioning allowed for up to 2\^32-1 sectors, i.e. 4294967295 of them which multiplied by 512 makes a nice 2199023255040 bytes or 2.2 Tib or 1,9999999995 Tb. (usually disks are 2.0 Tib).

Whether the disk is an AF format or not, i.e. if it has 4096 bytes sectors exposed as fake 512 bytes ones or it is a native 4Kb (or a native 512 bytes ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)) might be another matter and something to check anyway.

![:duff:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> Windows logo appears to complete install, and BAM, shortly thereafter, the BSOD or hang almost always occurs
There is high CPU load at that time.  

Given a several years old machine do some maintenance: clean the CPU fan  
Often the dust prohibit air flow.  
Disassemble up to fan parts, remove the dust between fan and cooler  
[http://www.notebookc...lean-cpu-fan-2/](http://www.notebookcpufans.com/blog/category/clean-cpu-fan-2/ "External link")  
[http://www.dell.com/...re-m14x/manuals](http://www.dell.com/support/home/us/en/19/product-support/product/alienware-m14x/manuals "External link")  
Grease the axis too and assemble the machine again.

forumNotes.author: Guest_AnonVendetta_*
forumNotes.content:
It's been almost 2 months since my first post, and I'm a bit closer to digging down to the source(s) of my issue stated in thread title. I can now at least install Windows, both 8.1 and 7, and they do boot, but......

I recently replaced the failing primary drive with an SSD, which I've had zero issues with, and placed the Seagate 2TB in the optical caddy slot. Since both drives are practically new, I think it's safe to rule them out as the source. I've checked the health of both drives, as well as checking for drive errors, all tests came up clean.

Windows 8.1 has been behaving erratically in recent weeks, for instance, brief but constant hangs, higher than normal RAM usage even while idle, a few random BSODs here and there.

I tried going back to 7 last night, just to see if I would get different results, and for a few hrs at least, everything seemed fine, no lag, everything running smooth, etc. But then I tried to install Windows Updates, and somewhere along the line the system suddenly BSODed while I was trying to load a browser page. This is the worst time a crash can occur, and almost impossible to fix short of rolling back to a known good backup, but I hadn't had time to do that yet. 2 subsequent 7 reinstalls resulted in the system hanging at the Windows logo on initial boot after install completion. Several forced shutdowns/powerons finally got setup to finish, and upon arriving at the desktop I immediately ran an SFC /scannow, to my surprise no corrupt files were found and the system didn't destabilize. I'm now attempting to install updates again to see what results I will get.

In the meantime, this narrows the most likely culprits down to bad RAM or a failing battery. I have briefly tested both RAM sticks simultaneously for as long as I could (less than 1.5 hrs, not even 2 runs) but testing found no errors during that time. Since I'm replacing the RAM with 16GB anyway, it doesn't really matter, but I haven't been able to conclusively fault or rule the memory out one way or another.

One question though, Dell's diagnostic built into the BIOS definitely indicates a failing battery, but isn't this unlikely to be the cause? I ask this because notebooks can generally run without a battery if they're plugged into AC power, which mine nearly always is. Also, how can I know whether the power supply (brick/charging cord) may also be bad? By coincidence a friend recently bought a model that is 100% identical to mine, except he has an HDD rather than an SSD, and no optical caddy. My PSU charges/powers his notebook just fine (couldn't persuade him to temp-swap other parts LOL).

On another sidenote, I can't, by necessity replace my modded BIOS with any of the official BIOSes, since the one I have restores my laptop's ability to run at SATA 3 speeds rather than being artificially throttled (by Dell) to SATA 2. This would slow my SSD down and this is unacceptable. I've ran benchmarks to check the speed difference and it is definitely noticeable. I will rule out UEFI for now, only considering it as a last resort. I'm convinced this is a matter of hardware issues, not firmware mode.

If all else fails I may need to seek the advice of an experienced technician for a comprehensive diagnosis.

Thanks in advance!

**Edited by AnonVendetta, 08 June 2015 - 02:49 AM.**

forumNotes.author: Guest_AnonVendetta_*
forumNotes.content:
So.........I just got the \*same\* BSOD at the same point in the Windows Update process, at update #151, which was something to do with the .Net Framework. I looked up from my phone just in time to see the crash message:

KERNEL_DATA_INPAGE_ERROR

I have my page file in another partition on the Seagate HDD in the caddy, to reduce hits on the SSD. I wonder if it would have made any difference if I either had no page file, or simply left it on the SSD instead.

And the errors from before, about "an attempt was made to execute to non-executable memory" and "bugcode_USB_driver" (no USB devices were connected at the time of the crash).

This is smelling more and more like a RAM issue to me, despite my RAM having previously passing all MemTest86+ tests.

forumNotes.author: Guest_AnonVendetta_*
forumNotes.content:
After some long thinking I've decided to simply install a Linux Mint root partition on the SSD, along with a swap and /home partition on the HDD. All Windows data is being moved to an external drive and both internal drives are being dedicated to Linux for up to a month. I figure it's best to reduce the overall hits on the SSD in the short and long term by not burdening it with Windows installs that will simply continue to crash, etc for whatever reason(s) unknown to me at this time, and will continue to do so until the unknowns are fixed.

I'm going to run under this setup until I can replace both the RAM and the battery, then try again later to see if my issues are solved. If not, then something else is obviously interfering.

As far as the KERNEL_DATA_INPAGE_ERROR, I've read it's due to disk errors/failure/failing, but SMART tests have revealed that both drives are fine and have neither bad sectors nor pending bad sectors. Chkdsk/Checkdisk revealed no errors either. The latest BSOD along this line appeared to mentioned NTFS.sys, but it flashed by too fast for me to read it all. I really do hope this is just a bad RAM/battery issue rather than bad ram sockets, because that will mean the motherboard needs to be replaced, in which case I'll either sell the laptop as-is or junk it. I also tried without a page file but got the same BSOD as before, which to me means that the page file itself couldn't be the issue since it didn't exist at that time.

I'm just pissed in regards to the contradictory results I'm getting. Testing shows RAM as fine, but some of the issues I'm experiencing clearly implicate the RAM as a factor. And yet other errors indicate the disks/volume(s) could be bad, yet both drives are seemingly fine, and new.

I just find it amazing how Linux can carry along unscathed under the same conditions that continually either crash Windows or cause erratic behavior, bad overall performance, etc. The only explanations are either that Linux is a more resilient and well-designed OS, and moreover, seemingly superior in many ways.

**Edited by AnonVendetta, 08 June 2015 - 06:05 AM.**

forumNotes.author: RoyM
forumNotes.content:
Thanks Steve, exactly what I was thinking, and the reason it may be working fine with Linux is no SATA3???.

It is correct that a motherboard will run without a battery, but a failing battery, i.e. (shorted) which is what they usually do.

They actually short out internally, If the short is great enough, you could end up frying the regulator which supplies that failing battery.

P.S. If you don't want to lose all your Bios Setting when replacing the battery, Power up and boot to a floppy or something quick.

while powered-up, 'carefully replace your battery', then reboot, "I may get flamed for this suggestion", but I will do it in a pinch,

and have had no issues in doing so, But just a warning, one slip-up, and you could brick your hardware.

Happy Troubleshooting

Regards

RoyM

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
The Real Time Clock and CMOS settings are normally connected to a separate small NiCd battery on laptops. Otherwise it would lose the time and date every time the battery was removed for a length of time. Most BIOS settings are held in EEROM these days and are not battery-backed.

If there is a problem with SATA 3, then when running linux, it could be just running at SATA 2, or it could be running at SATA 3 but have better error detection. For instance, many drivers will switch to a lower speed if it starts to detect CRC data errors.

P.S. Some Windows drivers will do this (depends on how well the driver is written). If so, you can often look at the Windows Event Log for any controller errors being reported. You may also see SMART errors being reported by the HDD (Data UDMA CRC errors).

e.g. If you run RMPrepUSB then press Ctrl-D for Disk Doctor, then select the suspect HDD and click on Synchronous Read, it will read all sectors on the drive and then report all SMART errors and Windows Event Log errors that occurred during the read.

See [http://www.rmprepusb...mprepusb-manual](http://www.rmprepusb.com/home/rmprepusb-manual "External link") **Q56 - How do I use Disk Doctor GUI?**

forumNotes.author: RoyM
forumNotes.content:
There is no separate battery on motherboards, there is usually only one CR2032 3V battery.  
And when you do remove this battery, it does lose it's date+time, and will usually reset to default CMOS settings.  
Same as if you were to short the CMOS reset pins.  
To temporarily hold CMOS settings that are contained in the EE'P'ROM when the battery is removed,  
a super-cap will be used to hold power for a short time, which is why you will hear,  
(to reset your bios, unplug the power cable from your pc power supply,  
remove your battery, and then wait for 5 to 10 minutes before reinstalling battery).  
FYI: EEPROM= Electronically Erasable, Programmable, Read Only Memory \<-- And I didn't even have to look that one up.  
Regards  
RoyM

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
It's a *laptop*not a PC. They typically do not have a CR2032 coin cell, they usually have a separate battery attached by two flying leads to save on PCB space. Also, PCs and laptops don't have super-caps (they are expensive and there is no need) - they just have ordinary low-esr caps for smoothing/reservoir protected by diodes and resistors. They do still need to be discharged (due to very low current consumption of the RTC circuit) however (or left for 30 mins or so).

As I said most BIOS settings are held in EEROM not in the battery-backed CMOS these days - as well as the dozens ofdifferent BIOS settings, Windows SLIC and UEFI boot preferences are held in EEROM. EEROMs are not battery-backed (same as flash memory is not battery backed).

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
The SSD UDMA CRC Error Count is showing as 97% health and the Raw count has 2664 (which could mean it had 2664 instances of errors).

In contrast, the ST2000 shows 100% health and only 67 Raw count errors.

So it does indicate that the SSD in particular is getting UDMA data transfer CRC errors.

Sometimes this can be due to cheap SATA cables (DON'T bundle them together - keep each SATA cable separate and well away from each other!). Many people try to bundle their cables together to keep them tidy but this is very bad! It can cause interference between cables. I have seen this with both SATA and IDE cables. I have also seen poor quality SATA cables cause data problems. This is not 'rumour' or 'conjecture' but it is from 30 years of direct personal experience in a factory which has built millions of PCs/notebooks.

If you are using good quality, shortish, nicely separated SATA cables, then the errors may indicate a data transfer problem with the mainboard/chipset. The only way to fix that is - do not use SATA3.

forumNotes.author: Guest_AnonVendetta_*
forumNotes.content:
steve6375's suggestions about my modded BIOS and its' supposed SATA fix appears to be spot-on. It now seems that running in SATA 3 was the primary source of my system instabilities. At this point I've managed to rule out every other hardware component as the source of my problems.

I flashed another version of my BIOS that simply had the hidden menus unlocked, but with no other mods/fixes. Windows 7 booted on the 1st try after that, the update process completed successfully (no BSOD at #151), no crashes. The only issue I've ran into is that 7 will periodically hang on the Windows logo while rebooting, but no crashes or bad system files as a result, just a hard poweroff/reboot to solve it. It mostly seems to appear while coldbooting, but rarely if ever during reboots. This may be indicative of yet another issue I'm not yet aware of.

I'm working with some guys that say they've gotten SATA 3 working on my model, and stable. I'd like to know their methods so I can experiment. But for now, SATA 2 seems more stable for the most part. I have proof (screenshots) which I'll post later. But for I dont have any time left to continue typing, so I'll post back later with more details and questions.

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> The only issue I've ran into is that 7 will periodically hang on the Windows logo while rebooting, but no crashes or bad system files as a result, just a hard poweroff/reboot to solve it.
Some driver dosn't report success, waiting for proper hardware answer.  

The HDD did run at SATA2 mode before and showed CRC errors nontheless. This can be the caddy case.  
They should be fixed now, not increase anymore.  
Post current CRC error rate. Do they increase still?  

> I'm working with some guys that say they've gotten SATA 3 working on my model, and stable.
Did you get any reports so far?  

Compare all hardware, CPU, GPU and disks.  
Different diskt tranfer rate gives different results. The SATA controller may run at less temperature at a HDD and higher at a SSD.  

And production tolerances may cause different results, unfortunately this behaviour is not logically explnationable.
